summary: The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Iowa today entered a final judgment against Jarrod Dale Majors, Jr., a 17-year-old high school senior who was sentenced to a mandatory minimum prison term of seventeen and one-half years.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on May 30, 2002, Majors entered his home, hid inside the closet of the master bedroom, and awaited the Peckhams' return home. As alleged in the complaint, he used a ski mask and gloves to hide his identity and sought to avoid detection. The complaint alleges that Majors then entered into a plea agreement in which he agreed to be permanently enjoined from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The settlement is subject to court approval.  The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by John Rymas of the Chicago Regional Office. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Iowa Department of Corrections in this matter.  For further information, see Press Release No. 17-20-20, March 5, 2018. Â The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investigative AlertÂ to encourage defendants to check the background of anyone who has been charged with a felony by using theÂ instant search tool onÂ the SEC'sÂ Adviser.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Majors.  In a related matter, the SEC today announced that it has obtained a court order halting the pending sentencing of Majors on the basis of insufficient evidence to determine whether he is competent to participate in the sentencing of a defendant. The court also issued an order suspending Majors from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  On August 2, 2018, the court granted the SEC a temporary restraining order and ordered Majors to return to his home state of Iowa to be re-admitted to the institution of a court-ordered minimum sentence.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint, the defendant consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the federal securities laws, orders him to pay a civil penalty of five years, and imposes a five-year officer-and-director bar against him. The judge also granted the court's motion for a preliminary injunction against further violations of Section 15(a)(2) of
